Award.AwardTitle: Critical Raindrop Characteristics: Fall Speed, Shape, and Size Distributions
Award.AbstractNarration:
The prevailing paradigm in radar meteorology, and precipitation science more generally, has been the assumption that raindrops fall at terminal velocity. However, recent research suggests this is not always the case, revealing an important new aspect of rain that requires further exploration. Under this project a field study designed to uncover new fundamental physics of raindrop fall characteristics will be conducted. More specifically this effort seeks to develop an improved predictive capability for raindrop fall velocity, chord ratio, and size distribution. It is hypothesized deviations from more traditionally-computed terminal velocities may induce deviations from equilibrium chord ratios and in turn introduce errors in inferred drop size distributions. This raises several new questions, the two most important being: (1) What are the actual raindrop fall velocities, chord ratios, and size distributions?; and (2) What are the governing environmental factors and processes responsible for deviations of these quantities away from their equilibrium values, and how can such deviations be predicted for specific conditions (e.g., rainfall rates)? Supported investigators will measure raindrop fall velocity, diameter, and shape using a state-of-the-art high-speed camera and digital image analysis system to seek answers to these and other questions.

The intellectual merit of this effort rests in development and interpretation of a unique microphysical dataset that will exploited to uncover raindrop fall characteristics, with a focus on providing relationships with varying rainfall conditions. This approach should lead to improved parameterizations for the drop-size distributions and chord ratio (i.e. drop oblateness, to which polarization-diverse radars are particularly sensitive) in falling precipitation of various types and intensities. This work is thought to be the first systematic study of the actual fall velocity of raindrops and its effects on raindrop geometry and size distribution. Broader impacts will include improved predictive capability for precipitation fall speeds, chord ratios and size distributions, as well as their relationship to rain rates as commonly derived from dual-polarization radar data. These efforts are anticipated to lead to improved retrievals of rainfall rates and accumulations, which may in turn benefit flood prediction, management of water resources, and related inputs to weather, hydrologic and climatological models. Additionally, knowledge gained will serve to improve interpretation of data from a large installed base of Joss-Waldvogel type disdrometers, which typically require a priori assumption of fallspeed to accurately infer rainfall rate. Precipitation research infrastructure at Clemson University will be enhanced through development of an instrumented field site, which will serve as an educational platform for undergraduate and graduate students. Related results will be disseminated via students' dissertations and the peer-reviewed literature.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF project was (i) to investigate critical raindrop characteristics such as raindrop size, shape, and fall speed using accurate digital imaging, and (ii) to advance our fundamental understanding of the rainfall microstructure and radar rainfall retrieval capabilities in the light of these accurate observations.  To achieve these goals and relevant project objectives, a novel optical-type disdrometer that is called as the High-speed Optical Disdrometer (HOD) was developed as part of this project.  Disdrometer is an instrument that is typically used for measurement of precipitation microphysical characteristics such as hydrometeor size distributions, shapes, and fall speeds as well as identification of precipitation type.  In addition to having these observational capabilities of a typical disdrometer, the HOD also has a unique capability of observing individual raindrops for a period of time to provide detailed information on the raindrop dynamics (e.g. oscillations) and interactions with other raindrops (e.g. raindrop collisions).  We published the details of this new technology, including its hardware and software, and its capabilities as demonstrated through field observations.  Our efforts on this new technology as part of this project and our synergistic efforts as part of the NSF Award # 1612717 paved the road for other HOD-like systems to be developed and commercialized.

While this research involved mainly field experimentation, we also conducted a limited scope laboratory experimentation to investigate the fall speeds and shapes of free falling water drops using high-speed imaging.  Our publications from our laboratory efforts provided the details of raindrop dynamics during acceleration to the terminal speed, and identified fall distances for oscillating, non-oscillating, and equilibrium-shaped drops as well as for non-terminal and terminal drops.  Our findings are of importance for understanding the transient dynamics of raindrops as well as for facilitating optimum experimental laboratory simulations of natural rainfall.  The transient dynamics of raindrops and deviations of raindrop characteristics from the predicted equilibrium values affect radar rainfall retrievals.  We investigated the combined effects of raindrop fall speed and axis ratio deviations from predicted equilibrium values on dual-polarization radar rainfall estimations.  Our investigations showed that realistic combinations of raindrop fall speed and axis ratio deviations induce significant radar rain rate estimation errors.  Our relevant publications documented these findings in detail and discussed the importance of accurate measurements and parameterizations of raindrop characteristics.  

This NSF project facilitated establishment of outdoor rainfall laboratories at Clemson University and at the University of Texas at San Antonio.  These infrastructures, equipped with the HOD and various standard meteorological instruments, provided a research and educational platform for a large number of graduate and undergraduate students.  Our field measurements at these facilities during a large number of rainfall events throughout the project period yielded a massive dataset.  These observations using the HOD were unique and revealed a wealth of new fundamental information on rainfall microphysical processes.  For example, we presented the first-time observations of raindrop collisions in rainfall events in one of our publications from this project.  These observations provided a critical support to the raindrop collision process in concluding a long-standing debate on the controlling physical process, raindrop collision versus spontaneous raindrop breakup, for the raindrop size distribution (DSD) evolution from cloud to ground level.  Our study demonstrated that scientific efforts should be guided towards the collision-driven DSD evolution paradigm, which is now technologically possible to investigate with the availability of the HOD.  In a follow-up study, we investigated the wind effects on the DSD shape.  Using a large dataset from a comprehensive field campaign, we showed that increasing wind speeds modify the DSD shapes by increasing the number of small drops and decreasing the number of large drops, and raindrop collision process controls the DSD shape modification.  Our findings are of importance in DSD parameterizations that are essential to a wide variety of applications such as radar rainfall retrievals and hydrologic models.  In addition to our investigations on rainfall microphysical processes, we also developed a new radar rainfall estimation algorithm, called RESID in short, for dual-polarization radars.  In our relevant publications, we demonstrated the capabilities of the RESID by comparing its performance with two benchmark algorithms through the use of rain gauge measurements from two different comprehensive field campaigns at different geographic locations.  This comparison showed favorable performance of our algorithm and approach.  As such, the RESID will likely provoke new radar rainfall retrieval algorithm development efforts that will utilize similar approaches.  Improvements in radar rainfall estimations using operational radar algorithms have great practical significance in a wide variety of societal applications such as water resources management and flash-flood warning and management.

Overall, all of the set goals of this NSF project were achieved and the project was successfully completed.  Findings and products of this project are expected to have significant scientific and broader impacts on a variety of disciplines and beneficiaries related to rainfall observations, estimations, and predictions.
